George Penrose Kennedy Young was born in 1858, named for another architect. After studying at Perth Academy, he was articled to his father in 1875. After a short period as his assistant, he spent a year in London, where he studied architecture under Professor Thomas Roger Smith at University College London (where he was prizeman in construction in 1881) and drawing under Alphonse Legros at the Slade School. He passed the qualifying exam in 1885 and was admitted Royal Institute of British Architects on 8 June, his proposers being John Honeyman (St Matthew's Church), Thomas Lennox Watson and John Burnet Sr. Shortly thereafter, he married Charlotte Anne Conacher. That same year, 1885, Young formed a partnership his son, George, continuing a business founded by George's grandfather. Their office was at 42 Tay Street,Transactions of Session, Volume 7 (1908), p. 35 part of Perth's Victoria Buildings, which they designed."GPK Young" – Perthshire Society of Natural Science George became sole partner on his father's death on 2 December, 1895.
